meanings.def: an object in the shape of a circle, usually made of gold and precious stones, that a king or queen wears on his or her head on official occasions
examples: The crown was placed upon the new monarch's head.
the emperor's jewel-encrusted crown

meanings.def: the government of a country, thought of as being represented by a king or queen
examples: land owned by the Crown
a Minister of the Crown
Who's appearing for the Crown (= bringing a criminal charge against somebody on behalf of the state) in this case?
a piece of Crown land

meanings.def: the position or power of a king or queen
examples: She refused the crown (= refused to become queen).
his claim to the French crown
He succeeded to the crown of Spain.
In 1553 the crown passed from Edward VI to Mary.
In 1688 the crown was offered to William and Mary.

meanings.def: a circle of flowers, leaves, etc. that is worn on somebody’s head, sometimes as a sign of victory
the position of winning a sports competition
examples: She is determined to retain her Wimbledon crown.
He lost his world crown to the Korean champion.
He won the final race of the season to clinch the world crown.

meanings.def: the top part of the head or a hat
examples: There were raindrops on his bald crown.
She swept her hair into a bun at the crown of her head.

meanings.def: the highest part of something
examples: the crown of a hill
from the crown of the final bend

meanings.def: the part of a plant just above and below the ground
examples: Roses bloom on shoots that sprout from the crown of the mother plant.

meanings.def: the top of a tree or other plant
examples: Nests were built high in the crowns of trees.

meanings.def: an artificial cover for a damaged tooth
the part of the tooth that is above the gum
anything in the shape of a crown, especially as a decoration or a badge
a unit of money in several European countries
examples: Czech crowns

meanings.def: an old British coin worth five shillings (= now 25p)
the most attractive or valuable part of something
examples: The Knightsbridge branch is the jewel in the crown of a 500-strong chain of stores.

idioms.def: the most attractive or valuable part of something
examples: The Knightsbridge branch is the jewel in the crown of a 500-strong chain of stores.

meanings.def: to put a crown on the head of a new king or queen as a sign of royal power in a ceremony at which they officially become king or queen
examples: be crowned Queen Elizabeth was crowned in 1953.
be crowned + noun The prince was soon to be crowned King of England.

meanings.def: to form or cover the top of something
examples: be crowned with something His head was crowned with a mop of brown curls.

meanings.def: to make something complete or perfect, especially by adding an achievement, a success, etc.
examples: crown something The award of the Nobel Prize has crowned a glorious career in physics.
be crowned with something Their efforts were finally crowned with success.

meanings.def: to hit somebody on the head
to put an artificial cover on a tooth
examples: have something/be crowned I've had one of my teeth crowned.

meanings.def: used to say that something is the final and worst event in a series of unpleasant or annoying events
examples: It was cold and raining, and, to crown it all, we had to walk home.

idioms.def: used to say that something is the final and worst event in a series of unpleasant or annoying events
examples: It was cold and raining, and, to crown it all, we had to walk home.
